sections.heading: What is の vs こと?
sections.content:
Both の and こと turn verbs and clauses into noun phrases, but they have different nuances and usage contexts. の is more casual, conversational, and concrete, while こと is more formal, written, and abstract. Some patterns require one or the other specifically.

の style: 泳ぐのが好き "I like swimming" (casual) こと style: 泳ぐことが好き "I like swimming" (formal) Similar but different feel

children.heading: の = conversational/concrete
children.content: 見るのが好き "I like watching" Casual speech Direct perception

children.heading: こと = formal/abstract
children.content: 見ることが好き "I like watching" Written style General concept

children.heading: の more casual
children.content: 料理するのは楽しい "Cooking is fun" Everyday conversation Natural speech

children.heading: こと more formal
children.content: 料理することは楽しい "Cooking is fun" Written language Formal contexts

children.heading: Simple statements
children.content: 読むのが好き = 読むことが好き "I like reading" Both acceptable Choice of style

children.heading: Importance statements
children.content: 大切なのは努力だ 大切なことは努力だ "What's important is effort" Both work の slightly more casual

sections.heading: When You MUST Use こと

children.heading: ことができる (can/able to)
children.content: Correct: 泳ぐことができる ✓ Wrong: 泳ぐのができる ⚠️ "Can swim" Fixed pattern Only こと works

children.heading: ことがある (experience)
children.content: Correct: 行ったことがある ✓ Wrong: 行ったのがある ⚠️ "Have been there" Must use こと

children.heading: ことにする (decide to)
children.content: Correct: 行くことにした ✓ Wrong: 行くのにした ⚠️ "Decided to go" Only こと

children.heading: ことになる (it's decided)
children.content: Correct: 転勤することになった ✓ Wrong: 転勤するのになった ⚠️ "It was decided I'll transfer" Fixed expression

children.heading: Perception verbs (see/hear)
children.content: Better: 彼が走るのを見た ✓ Less natural: 彼が走ることを見た △ "I saw him running" の more natural Direct perception

children.heading: With をやめる (stop doing)
children.content: Better: 吸うのをやめた ✓ Awkward: 吸うことをやめた △ "Stopped smoking" の preferred

children.heading: Casual conversation
children.content: Natural: 寝るのを忘れた ✓ Stiff: 寝ることを忘れた △ "Forgot to sleep" の sounds natural

children.heading: の for concrete actions
children.content: ここで食べるのはだめ "Eating here is not allowed" Specific situation Immediate context

children.heading: こと for abstract concepts
children.content: 健康を守ることは大切だ "Protecting health is important" General principle Abstract idea

children.heading: Spoken preference: の
children.content: 走るのが好き "I like running" Natural speech Conversational

children.heading: Written preference: こと
children.content: 運動することは健康に良い "Exercising is good for health" Essays, reports Formal writing

children.heading: 好き/嫌い (like/dislike)
children.content: Both OK: 泳ぐのが好き 泳ぐことが好き の more casual こと more formal

children.heading: 忘れる (forget)
children.content: Better: 言うのを忘れた OK: 言うことを忘れた の more natural

children.heading: 知っている (know)
children.content: Better: 彼が来たことを知っている OK: 彼が来たのを知っている こと for facts の also acceptable

children.heading: Fixed patterns only use こと
children.content: ことができる - can ことがある - have experience ことにする - decide to ことになる - it's decided ことがない - never (experience) Cannot use の

children.heading: のだ/んだ (explanatory)
children.content: 雨が降っているのだ "It's raining (you see)" 知らなかったんだ "I didn't know (explanatory)" Only の, not こと Different function

children.heading: の as "one"
children.content: 赤いの "The red one" 大きいの "The big one" Replaces noun Only の works

children.heading: こと cannot replace nouns
children.content: Wrong: 赤いこと ⚠️ Correct: 赤いの ✓ こと is abstract only

children.heading: こと for written rules
children.content: 静かにすること "Be quiet" (written rule) 走らないこと "Don't run" (sign) Formal instructions Only こと

children.heading: が好き (like)
children.content: Casual: 読むのが好き Formal: 読むことが好き Both acceptable Register difference

children.heading: は大切だ (important)
children.content: Casual: 休むのは大切だ Formal: 休むことは大切だ Both work Style choice

children.heading: ができる (can)
children.content: Only こと: 泳ぐことができる Wrong: 泳ぐのができる ⚠️ Must use こと Fixed pattern

children.heading: が時々ある (sometimes)
children.content: 行くことがある "Sometimes go" Must use こと Frequency expression

children.heading: Choosing words
children.content: In speech → prefer の In writing → prefer こと With できる → must use こと With perception verbs → prefer の Context determines choice

children.heading: Using の with ができる
children.content: Wrong: 泳ぐのができる ⚠️ Correct: 泳ぐことができる ✓ "Can swim" Must use こと

children.heading: Using こと too much in speech
children.content: Unnatural: 見ることを見た ⚠️ Natural: 見るのを見た ✓ "Saw (someone) watching" の sounds better

children.heading: Mixing up replacement function
children.content: Wrong: 赤いこと ⚠️ Correct: 赤いの ✓ "The red one" Only の replaces nouns

children.heading: Emotional vs factual
children.content: の: More personal/emotional 泣くのを見た "Saw (someone) crying" (personal observation) こと: More objective/factual 泣くことは悪くない "Crying is not bad" (general statement) Subtle difference

children.heading: Quick reference
children.content: Casual speech → の Formal writing → こと Perception verbs → の ができる pattern → こと がある (experience) → こと にする/になる → こと Replacing nouns → の Explanatory のだ → の Context guides choice

children.heading: General preferences
children.content: Both OK: 勉強するのが好き 勉強することが好き "I like studying" の = casual こと = formal Choose by context

children.heading: Standard usage
children.content: の and こと Universal patterns Same throughout Japan

children.heading: Basic
children.content: の examples: 泳ぐのが好き (casual) "I like swimming" 見るのを忘れた "I forgot to watch" 赤いのがいい "I want the red one" こと examples: 泳ぐことができる (must use こと) "Can swim" 日本に行ったことがある (must use こと) "I have been to Japan" 行くことにした (must use こと) "I decided to go"

children.heading: Intermediate
children.content: Interchangeable: 日本語を勉強するのは難しい (casual) 日本語を勉強することは難しい (formal) "Studying Japanese is difficult" Must use の: 彼が歌うのを聞いた "I heard him singing" Must use こと: 毎日運動することができます "I can exercise every day" 富士山に登ったことがありますか "Have you ever climbed Mt. Fuji?" 東京に住むことになりました "It was decided I'll live in Tokyo"
